claim: Lorenzo de Medici's patronage of Da Vinci was exclusive.

supporting.text: Lorenzo de Medici was known for his exclusive patronage of prominent artists, and Da Vinci was one of the most sought-after talents of the Renaissance.

attacks.text: Lorenzo de Medici was known for his exclusive patronage of prominent artists, and Da Vinci was one of the most sought-after talents of the Renaissance.
Da Vinci also received patronage from other prominent figures like Ludovico Sforza, indicating Lorenzo's patronage was not exclusive.
Lorenzo de Medici's patronage was primarily focused on other artists like Michelangelo, not Da Vinci, suggesting Da Vinci was not his exclusive focus.
Historical records show Da Vinci spent significant time in Milan under Sforza's patronage, further undermining the claim of exclusivity with Lorenzo.

supporting.text: Historical records indicate that Da Vinci also received patronage from other influential figures, such as Ludovico Sforza, during the same period.

attacks.text: Historical records indicate that Da Vinci also received patronage from other influential figures, such as Ludovico Sforza, during the same period.
Ludovico Sforza's patronage of Da Vinci was intermittent and less substantial compared to Lorenzo de Medici's consistent support.
Da Vinci's primary works and innovations were developed under Lorenzo de Medici's patronage, suggesting his support was more exclusive in practice.
Historical records show that Da Vinci sought patronage from multiple sources to ensure financial stability, not because Lorenzo's patronage was non-exclusive.

supporting.text: Lorenzo de Medici's focus on cultivating a select group of artists for his court suggests that his patronage of Da Vinci was likely exclusive at the time.

attacks.text: Lorenzo de Medici's focus on cultivating a select group of artists for his court suggests that his patronage of Da Vinci was likely exclusive at the time.
Historical records show that Da Vinci received patronage from multiple patrons, including Ludovico Sforza, during the same period.
Lorenzo de Medici's patronage network was extensive, and while he focused on a select group, he did not prevent them from seeking other patrons.
Da Vinci's own letters indicate that he sought patronage from multiple sources to secure his financial stability.
The concept of exclusive patronage was rare in Renaissance Italy, as artists often worked for multiple patrons to maximize opportunities.

supporting.text: Da Vinci's extensive work for various patrons across Italy demonstrates that his relationship with Lorenzo de Medici was not exclusive.

attacks.text: Da Vinci's extensive work for various patrons across Italy demonstrates that his relationship with Lorenzo de Medici was not exclusive.
While Da Vinci worked for others, Lorenzo de Medici was his primary patron during a significant period of his early career.
Historical records show that Da Vinci's most influential works were created under Lorenzo's patronage, suggesting a dominant relationship.
Many artists of the Renaissance worked for multiple patrons simultaneously, which does not necessarily diminish the exclusivity of their relationship with a primary patron.
Da Vinci's work for other patrons was often minor or incomplete, while his projects for Lorenzo were more substantial and completed.

supporting.text: The Medici family's dominance in Florentine arts and politics during Lorenzo's rule implies that he could have secured exclusive rights to Da Vinci's services.

attacks.text: The Medici family's dominance in Florentine arts and politics during Lorenzo's rule implies that he could have secured exclusive rights to Da Vinci's services.
Da Vinci worked for other patrons, such as Ludovico Sforza in Milan, during Lorenzo de Medici's lifetime, contradicting exclusivity.
Lorenzo de Medici's influence was primarily in Florence, while Da Vinci's work for Sforza occurred in Milan, outside Medici's direct control.
Patronage contracts from this era rarely included exclusivity clauses, making the claim historically unlikely.
The Medici family's political power could have allowed them to enforce informal exclusivity despite lack of written contracts.

supporting.text: Da Vinci's independent projects and commissions outside of Florence contradict the idea of exclusive patronage by Lorenzo de Medici.

attacks.text: Da Vinci's independent projects and commissions outside of Florence contradict the idea of exclusive patronage by Lorenzo de Medici.
Lorenzo de Medici's influence and network extended beyond Florence, possibly facilitating Da Vinci's external commissions.
Historical records show Da Vinci sought patronage independently, such as his work for Ludovico Sforza in Milan, without Medici involvement.
Lorenzo de Medici's primary focus was on Florentine artists, and his direct support for Da Vinci's external projects is undocumented.
Exclusive patronage does not necessarily mean Da Vinci was prohibited from other work, only that Medici was his primary patron.
Da Vinci's most significant early works, like 'The Adoration of the Magi,' were directly commissioned by the Medici family.
